Dave and Charlie,

That's fabulous news! Should be a lot of fun to play aro=
und with.
Thanks for your prompt and very helpful replies.

Rick



--- In =
cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Rick -
=
> 
> What you want to do is no problem. Simply define ionized species as  
=
> containing the special element "E".  Foe example, K+ would contain  
> on=
e atom of  potassium, and -1 atoms of "E".
> Cantera comes with some thermo=
 files, at least one of which has the  
> thermo properties for gaseous ele=
ctrons.   As far as equilibrium  
> (Saha equation), the solvers handle cha=
rged species fine, and the  
> results would be the same as computed from t=
he Saha equation.  Take a  
> look at the Python demo "multiphase_plasma.py=
" in the demos/Python/ 
> equilibrium folder. It has both multiple condense=
d phases and ionized  
> gaseous species.
> 
> Dave
> 
> 
> 
> On May 24, 2=
006, at 11:34 AM, Rick_Muller wrote:
> 
> > I'm interested in whether anyon=
e is using Cantera to simulate  
> > reactions
> > of ionized species such =
as would occur in a weakly ionized gas. It
> > seems to me that one could a=
ugment the normal kinetics that come out
> > of a GRI reaction mechanism wi=
th a Saha equation calculation of the
> > ionization process. However, this=
 would require that electrons be
> > treated as actual species in the react=
ion mechanism, and I don't know
> > whether there are serious problems in d=
oing this. Can anyone comment
> > on the suitability of this type of a mode=
l?
> >
> > Thanks in advance,
> >
> > Rick Muller
